title: SE(3) diffusion model with application to protein backbone generation. (arXiv:2302.02277v3 [cs.LG] UPDATED)
abstract: The design of novel protein structures remains a challenge in protein engineering for applications across biomedicine and chemistry. In this line of work, a diffusion model over rigid bodies in 3D (referred to as frames) has shown success in generating novel, functional protein backbones that have not been observed in nature. However, there exists no principled methodological framework for diffusion on SE(3), the space of orientation preserving rigid motions in R3, that operates on frames and confers the group invariance. We address these shortcomings by developing theoretical foundations of SE(3) invariant diffusion models on multiple frames followed by a novel framework, FrameDiff, for learning the SE(3) equivariant score over multiple frames. We apply FrameDiff on monomer backbone generation and find it can generate designable monomers up to 500 amino acids without relying on a pretrained protein structure prediction network that has been integral to previous methods. We find our sa

Title: SE(3) diffusion model with application to protein backbone generation. (arXiv:2302.02277v3 [cs.LG] UPDATED)
Abstract: The design of novel protein structures remains a challenge in protein engineering for applications across biomedicine and chemistry. In this line of work, a diffusion model over rigid bodies in 3D (referred to as frames) has shown success in generating novel, functional protein backbones that have not been observed in nature. However, there exists no principled methodological framework for diffusion on SE(3), the space of orientation preserving rigid motions in R3, that operates on frames and confers the group invariance. We address these shortcomings by developing theoretical foundations of SE(3) invariant diffusion models on multiple frames followed by a novel framework, FrameDiff, for learning the SE(3) equivariant score over multiple frames. We apply FrameDiff on monomer backbone generation and find it can generate designable monomers up to 500 amino acids without relying on a pretrained protein structure prediction network that has been integral to previous methods. translated_title: 应用于蛋白质主链生成的SE（3）扩散模型
translated_abstract: 设计新型蛋白质结构仍然是生物医学和化学领域中的一项挑战。在这方面的工作中，一个三维刚性体（称为框架）上的扩散模型已经成功地生成了在自然界中没有观察到的新型功能蛋白主链。然而，在3D空间中的方向保持刚性运动的SE（3）扩散上缺乏明确的方法论框架，该框架在框架操作中保持群不变性。我们通过开发多个框架上SE（3）不变扩散模型的理论基础来解决这些缺点，然后提出了一种新的框架，FrameDiff，来学习多个框架上SE（3）等变分数。我们在单体背景生成上应用FrameDiff，并发现它可以生成可设计的单体背景，长达500个氨基酸，而不依赖于之前方法中必要的预训练蛋白质结构预测网络。我们发现我们的sa
tldr: 本文提出了SE（3）扩散模型及其理论基础，并使用FrameDiff框架在多个框架上学习SE（3）等变分数，成功生成可设计的长达500个氨基酸的单体背景。
en_tdlr: This paper proposes a SE(3) diffusion model with theoretical foundations and develops a novel framework, FrameDiff, for learning SE(3) equivariant score over multiple frames, successfully generating designable monomer backbones up to 500 amino acids without relying on a pretrained protein structure prediction network.
